title: Will Great Britain win more gold medals at the 2020 Olympics than the People's Republic of China?
preds: Based on current standings and future events.

Closer to 0 than 1. Mix of Covid infections and losses of 'guaranteed' medals early on. Plus, factoring in others' research about medal development over the last decade and the kind of young talent vacuum created by drug controversies.

https://www.gracenote.com/virtual-medal-table/
Quotes
Great Britian
(Tokyo 2020: 52 medals, 2016: 67 medals)
In 2016, Great Britain became the first country to win more Olympic medals four years after hosting than they won at home. The Gracenote Virtual Medal Table projects a drop of 15 medals in Tokyo this year from their 2016 total of 67. The British team is therefore likely to drop out of the top-three medal winning countries but 52 medals should be enough to achieve a fourth successive top-5 finish. The reduction in medals for Britain is partially due to lower expectations in cycling – track, gymnastics – artistic and rowing amongst other competitions. In 2016, those three sports accounted for nearly one third of British medals (22). In 2021 however, these sports could produce as few as five podium places. China
(Tokyo 2020: 66 medals, 2016: 70 medals)
China’s total of 70 medals in 2016 was the country’s lowest return since 2004 and the current Gracenote projection for Tokyo 2020 is lower than this. However, many members of the Chinese Olympic team have not competed since 2019 and may therefore be underrated by the Virtual Medal Table. China edged Great Britain into second place in Rio by a margin of three medals. This time, host nation Japan and the Russian Olympic Committee competitors could challenge China for second place on total medals. The data suggests that China will be well ahead of both on gold medals though. Team GB has to also compete against Japan who will have a stronger showing as its a home Olympics.   I hadn’t considered the thoughts on the cycling.  Many of the successful track team are now in their 30s and given the scandals it’s not clear that this team has as many good younger competitors.  Rowing is in a similar position after having a period with significant strong competitors.  If these two areas are not as strong there is a lot less opportunity for medals, let alone golds.  Yes Team GB might pick up a few from the new sports, but these are unlikely to be as many as are not taken else where. Reducing Team GB chances to hardly possible at all.

Gold Medal Counts for most recent Olympics (until 1992, when Winter/Summer games separated into alternating per 2 years, and the set of sports most closely resembles what it currently is): 2016: UK 27, China 26
2012 (London, UK): UK 29, China 38
2008 (Beijing, China): UK 19, China 48
2004: UK 9, China 32
2000: UK 11, China 28
1996: UK 1, China 16
1992: UK 5, China 16 Modeling naively using a normal distribution as a baseline, we have # golds distributed as UK ~ N(14.4, 10)
China ~ N(29.1, 10.7) So P(UK > China) = P(UK - China > 0) = P( N(-14.7, 14.6) > 0 ) = 16% The new sports added this year in the Tokyo Olympics are baseball/softball, karate, skateboarding, sports climbing, and surfing; I believe the UK has a better chance overall at gold medals in essentially every one of these events. This would probably adjust the expectation of UK medals up by a little. Also, the UK seems to be on an uptrend in the last 3 Olympics (getting 1 more gold than China in the 2016 Olympics), while China has seemed to stabilize at around ~30 golds (with the exception of the host nation year in 2008); I'll make small adjustments for these factors and bump my final estimate of the probability up to 20%.

In addition, for the past few olympics, the gold medal differences between China and GB have been more than 9 with the exception of Rio, where GB had one more medal the China. In addition, China is the leading team for Table tennis and Badminton, while GB is the leading team in Sailing. Over the past 3 Olympics China has gotten more gold medals in two out of the three Olympics and more total medals in all three. The notable difference is that Great Britain had more gold medals than China last year for the first time in a while (26 vs. 27). Additionally, there has been an interesting trend in China's gold and total medal count as it has significantly decreased over the past few Olympics. However, there are not too many data points so it is hard to make a strong trend about this. I think it is more important to look at the athletes they have and how their performances compare.  There are lots of odds around. The odds for China to win the most gold medals is +600, while the odds for Great Britain to win the most gold medals is +2500. However, a prediction of total medal count puts China at 38 with Great Britain at only 11. They cite possible poor performance in cycling – track, gymnastics – artistic and rowing which accounted for nearly one third of British total medals (22). Overall, I think it was important to try to balance these two things. Looking back at 2016, China had much higher odds of having more golds, however Great Britain still ended up getting more gold medals. As such, I think while the chance of Great Britain getting more gold medals than China is low, it is a very serious possibility and something that we need to consider.

first, we look at some historical results of GBR vs China. In the previous year, China barely got beat by GBR, and for Olympics previous to that, China has outdone GBR quite consistently. Posting around 7-10 more gold medals on average. Furthermore, if we dissect the result from the previous olympics where GBR beat China by one medal, about a third came from the three events cycling, gymnastics ,and rowing. Now, the projections for the combination of those three events are about a fifth as much. A reasonable distribution for the number of medals would be lognormal with mean 7, which would place about a 1% chance of putting them ahead of China, given all other events have the same mean number of gold medals as previous Olympics. Adding about a 2% from where the normal distributions would intersect at the left and right tails for the number of gold medals for China and GBR, respectively, for the remaining events (i.e. the probability that GBR beats China), would be barely less than 2%. We assume the means to be historical averages. The dependence between these distributions can be ignored given the specialty of the nations in different events in general.

Odds makers have the China medal count over/under around 36.5, where GB's is less than half at 13.5. GB isn't even third in expected gold medals, they're fourth behind hosts Japan. Their history is good though, finishing as the second highest gold medal count in 2016, one higher than China.  However, there is the factor that the games are back in Asia, and the last time the games were in Asia, China did exceptionally well, finishing with the highest gold medal count. With such a stark contrast in the expected values, I find it very unlikely this happens. It's not completely impossible though, because if GB gets about 10 more than expected and China gets 10 less, then it's a whole new ball game, but I give that a small chance to happen.
With the exception of the London Olympics, China have surpassed GB. I don't see a reversal of fortune in any Olympics soon

I'd normally put this at around 50/50 given some of the recent results. But the UK were still riding the wave of the team development during 2012 build up in 2016 when they beat China. This time around many of those stars have faded and equally there are many British olympians who have found it harder to train due to covid restrictions. This isn't the case for China, so I'm say they'll edge it.

Relevant historical period: 2 games. This is somewhat arbitrary but attempts captures two things. 1) the nature of a sporting 'system' - i.e. the Great Britain rowing team is strong because of a strong development program that fosters young athletes through their youth into later success. 2) The fact that most Olympic athletes only compete in one set of games, which means looking far into the past is not predictive of the future.  Base rate: China had more golds than GB in 2012 (38-29); GB had more gold medals than China in 2016 (27-26). Based on this alone, we might predict [GB's golds / Sum of China and GB's golds] = 46.67%. This however discounts the total medal tally, which is relevant because the margins between gold/silver/bronze are very tight (this is the Olympics after all). Using total medals, the base rate would be 45.05%. These values are relatively close in magnitude, so we naively take their average for a forecast of 45.67%.

Starting at the most broad base rate, let's say that gold medals are randomly distributed to people. China's population is 21 time that of GB, so they are expected to win 21 times the amount of medals as GB. While somewhat useful in measuring odds of a superhuman athlete being from China rather than GB, the Olympics feature the most talented athletes around the world. As many of the peers on my team have done, the historical performance of China has been 22.4 gold medals per game, and GB is only at 9.39. One additional consideration is that in many events, the gold and bronze aren't too far off, so silver and bronze medals by these countries should be considered as well. However, China averages 54.6 medals per game while GB averages 30.4 medals. Looking at current year predictions, China is forecasted to win 42 gold medals, while GB is forecasted to win only 20.
Let us consider what the possible scenarios are for GB to win more gold medals than China. If China's athletes are not allowed or unable to compete due to the pandemic, clearly that would result in fewer medals. The vaccine status is more prevalent in developed countries, but this risk is low since Olympic athletes are likely more readily available to access vaccines. Another case is that GB outperforms and beats China, but this is also very low likelihood since the sheer number of Chinese athletes makes it hard to prevent any gold medals from being earned. A more likely scenario is that the US beats China, resulting in China having a lot of silver medals and GB edging out in more esoteric events. Historically, GB has dominated events such as sailing and athletics, whereas China dominated in table tennis and badminton, neither of which US is particularly strong in. The most medals come from diving and swimming, where there are multiple events for medals, and so it's possible that the US sweeps swimming and essentially pushes China and GB to compete in their dominant sports. However, since China has won much more than GB in those respective sports with nearly 30 golds in each of weightlifting, diving, and table tennis, GB is likely still going to have fewer gold medals.
If we assume a difference of 12 medals (near historical averages) and a variance of 5, a normally distributed medal count suggests 5% chance GB has more gold medals. The US factor can sway both ways, so my overall prediction would still hover around 5%.

So for a base rate I would have to say that China will take more Gold medals than GB this year. 
To be truly accurate one should probably evaluate on an athlete/event level as opposed to bulk statistics.

Historically, China has always outperformed Great Britain at the Summer Olympics (except for Rio 2016) for a base rate of 1/9 (11.1%) if we count starting from the 1984 Olympics. Since Great Britain bested China in the last Olympic Games, one might expect to have a higher estimate than the base rate; however, in 2016, Great Britain won 7 gold (12 total) in cycling, 3 gold (5 total) in rowing, and 2 gold (7 total) in gymnastics. These gold wins account for 12 of their 27 total gold medals, but they are expected to perform significantly worse in the aforementioned sports. For example in cycling, British cyclists did not perform well in 2019 which will lead to a reduced roster for the upcoming Olympics. 2019 also marked the first year that a Grand Tour went without a British champions since 2014.

Historically, the only Olympics GB was ahead of China was Rio 2016. Also, not counting Rio, since 2000 at least, China always had more than 28 Gold; However, since 2008 - perhaps because 2012 Olympics were supposed to be in London - GB's performance boosted, but their gold medals count since 2008 is: 19, 29, and 26. On another note, the number of Silver medals also is higher for China - except in Rio2016 (23 to 18 for GB). Taking all these into account with the predictions from https://www.gracenote.com/virtual-medal-table/ thanks @Eolienne  I don't see GB beating China in Tokyo 2021. However, there is a big factor: the Covid19 effect. 
Another note: For countries like China, Russia, Iran etc , Olympic performance is a showcase of power. So, I'm guessing China took Tokyo seriously since Rio ended. But again: there is Covid19.

China has a much larger pool of citizens to get high performance athletes from.  Traditionally, China has been a top three country.  The only thing that could tip the scales are pandemic related. Perhaps China cannot send a full delegation, etc.
